TopicTitle: Hello. I'm the Synthetic Flying Machine.

Articles.Content:
Hello, everyone! I'm the Synthetic Flying Machine and I'm new.

I recently got back into Kerbal Space Program and just rocket science in general. I used to play it around a year ago just for fun.

I wouldn't do anything but build random stuff and crash. I doubt I even got into space more than twice.

But now that I've started playing it and actually gotten interested I've been trying to find good places to learn stuff about the game.

I've learned how to get into orbit using maneuvers from Scott Manley's tutorials but his tutorials don't seem to really go in depth about things.

It seems like he just expects you to know a lot of what he's talking about and me being the ultra beginner I am, don't

I literally just before making this forum account started reading The Missing Manual Volume 1. I can't say much about it because I've read about 1 sentence but hopefully it explains things little farther.

If anyone knows any other good tutorials that could help out someone that can barely make a good orbit, please reply with them. That would be greatly appreciated.

Well thanks for reading

Hey there and welcome to the KSP Forum!

I've got a tutorial that might help you (it also helped me learning the game) to learn the game, basic maneuvers, rocket construction etc. Look in my signature, it's called "Exploring the System - a design tutorial campaign" written by Pecan. I hope it helps you, and if you've got other questions, the forum is just the right place to ask. And don't wonder when you can't set an avatar / signature yet and your post won't appear instantly - a lot of people seem to be asking this these days - you are currently in the Curious George user group which was made to prevent spambots. After 3-5 posts everything will be fine and you can post like anyone else.

Have fun!

Thanks for explaining the avatar and signature thing, haha!

And I'll check out the tutorial. Thanks!
Welcome. Your comments and questions are also welcome in the tutorial thread. Thanks Volcanix :-)
